title: Remote Pay Cost of Living Adjuster
description: Calculate how much a remote salary offer is truly worth in your local city by applying cost-of-living index numbers.
methodSummary: Ratio = Your Local Index / Company HQ Index
Adjusted Pay = Base Salary Offer Ã— Ratio
assumptions: You must input your own local indices (such as from Numbeo or government metrics).
Relies on the baseline assumption that an index of 100 represents the average baseline comparison.
insights: A $100k offer from a company based in San Francisco (Index ~130) equates to roughly $70k in purchasing power if you live in a mid-tier Midwest city (Index ~90).
Many remote companies use exact index formulas to localize your pay. Understanding this math lets you negotiate effectively before accepting.

faqs.q: Where do I find these index numbers?
faqs.a: You can use public databases like Numbeo or Expatistan. Look for the 'Cost of Living Index' for the two respective cities.

faqs.q: What does an index of 100 mean?
faqs.a: An index of 100 is typically the baseline city (often New York City in global datasets). If a city has an index of 80, it is 20% cheaper than the baseline.
That depends entirely on the index you use. Make sure the index you look up explicitly says 'Cost of Living Plus Rent Index' if you are relocating.

faqs.q: Why is the adjusted pay lower?
faqs.a: If your local city index is lower than the company's HQ index, the mathematical 'purchasing power' translates to a lower adjusted value. It means you can buy the same standard of living for less.

faqs.q: Is it fair for companies to adjust pay by geography?
faqs.a: This is a heavily debated topic. Some companies pay strictly for value (no adjustment), while others maintain strict geographical pay bands to assure internal equity.

faqs.q: How can I use this to negotiate?
faqs.a: If you know the company uses cost of living indices, you can calculate the exact delta they are applying and counter-offer if their index source is flawed.
